ai:cl.c: Provides a complete working implementation of HTTP.

ai:a.c: Cancels the current download. Can also signal the end to a download if subscribed.
Entries in the HTTP response header can be read as key-values.
ai:a.p: ERR acGetKey(*Object, CSTRING Key, STRING Value, INT Size)

ai:i.c: The name of a key value.
Pointer to a buffer space large enough to hold the retrieved value.
Indicates the byte size of the Buffer.

ai:a.c: Options to pass in the HTTP method header can be set as key-values.
ai:a.p: ERR acSetKey(*Object, CSTRING Key, CSTRING Value)

ai:i.c: The name of the target key.
The string value to associate with Key.

ai:a.c: Writes data to objects that provide storage or output services.
ai:a.p: ERR acWrite(*Object, APTR Buffer, INT Length, INT Result)

ai:i.c: A buffer containing the data that will be written to the object.
The total number of bytes to write to the object.
This parameter with be updated with the total number of bytes written from the Buffer.

ai:f.c: Indicates the preferred buffer size for data operations.
This unused field value can be used for storing private data.
The initial connection timeout value, measured in seconds.
The byte length of incoming or outgoing content.
Defines the content-type for PUT and POST methods.
Indicates the current state of an HTTP object during its interaction with an HTTP server.
The data timeout value, relevant when receiving or sending data.
The default datatype format to use when passing data to a target object.
The error code received for the most recently executed HTTP command.
Optional flags.
The targeted HTTP server is specified here, either by name or IP address.
A callback routine can be defined here for incoming data.
Indicates download progress in terms of bytes received.
To upload HTTP content from a file, set a file path here.
Allows data to be sent from an object on execution of a POST command.
A valid HTTP URI must be specified here.
The HTTP instruction to execute is defined here (defaults to GET).
The transfer mode used when passing data to a targeted object.
Outgoing data can be sent procedurally using this callback.
To download HTTP content to a file, set a file path here.
Incoming data can be sent to the object referenced in this field.
The password to use when authenticating access to the server.
The HTTP path targeted at the host server.
The HTTP port to use when targeting a server.
The port to use when communicating with the proxy server.
The targeted HTTP server is specified here, either by name or IP address.
Identifies the realm during HTTP authentication.
Refers to a data buffer that is used to store all incoming content.
Set this field to define the length of a data transfer when issuing a POST command.
A callback routine can be defined here for monitoring changes to the HTTP state.
Indicates the HTTP status code returned on completion of an HTTP request.
Specifies the name of the user-agent string that is sent in HTTP requests.
The username to use when authenticating access to the server.
